title: Ability to stop a trace
body: Refs #81

title: Merging next_major_version into master
body:
This MR brings back all the commits added to `next_major_version` in the course of the last months into `master`, because I feel like ferrisetw may be ready to release a newer version.

However, we could try releasing 0.1.2 first (from the current master, e.g. to check docs.rs succeeds at generating its doc)

title: fix: retaining ownership of an array instead of returning a dangling pointer
body:
`ENABLE_TRACE_PARAMETERS` has a pointer (A) to an array of `EVENT_FILTER_DESCRIPTOR`s, which contains pointers (B) themselves. I cared about the lifetime of pointers A and B, but forgot about the lifetime of the array, which was actually dropped very soon :-(

Now this array is owned by `EnableTraceParameters`, which fixes this dangling pointer issue.

This bug could lead to failing enabling providers, with `EtwNativeError(IoError(Os { code: 87, kind: InvalidInput, message: "The parameter is incorrect." }))`

title: No longer ignoring a "Trace does not exist" error
body: I feel there is no reason to ignore this error (which basically means 'this trace does not exist").

title: Extended integration tests
body: This adds two minor checks in integration tests, to have slightly more coverage

title: Check property flags
body:
This depends on #75 .

This improves the `// Fixme: Check flags to see which values to get for the in_type`.
We're now checking an properly returning an error in case we do not support a property.

That's better than the current situation, but we could one day implement missing property types (that's #76)

title: Using the log crate rather than bare println/eprintln
body: Because using `println` and `eprintln` in a library crate is not a very good practise. `log` gives more control to the user binary

title: Clippy
body:
A few changes suggested by cargo-clippy, because why not

(first commits are #64 and #70 , which this PR depends on)

Clippy now only complains about test that use `if condition == false` rather than `if !condition`. But I find the former more readable, so I'm leaving them as-is. That's mainly a matter of taste, I am open to discussion in case you prefer the `if !condition` style

title: Enabled Dependabot
body: So that we are notified when a dependency can be upgraded

title: [minor] Better error handling
body: Better handling of errors in a windows function

title: Reviewed visibility
body:
This PR depends on #63 , #65 , #66 and #68 
(it does not depend on all of them feature-wise, but merging them first will avoid git conflicts, especially in the `use ....;` lines at the beginning of files)

This PR (or rather, its last 5 commits) reviews the visibility of many types and modules, so that the user-facing API and documentation only exposes what he will need.
* This makes it easier to read the doc
* This leaves us more room to do future changes that otherwise could be breaking (since breaking change in a public API requires a new major version. That's too bad for types that are not supposed to be used).

Maybe(?) some issues were pre-existing, but I think most of these too-widly-visible items were due to uncautious refactos of mine

title: Upgraded dependencies
body: This depends on #63 that must be merged first

title: Turbofish operator for try_parse
body:
This PR depends on #63 and #65 , as its first commits come from them.

This makes it possible to use the turbofish operator for `try_parse`, which is slightly more convenient than the current solution.
This improvement was already considered by @n4r1b quite a long time ago, since there was a 
`// TODO: Find a way to use turbofish operator`

title: Stronger types
body:
This PR depends on #63 that must be merged first

This uses more strongly-typed data

title: More integration tests
body: This PR depends on #63

title: fix parsing of wide strings
body:
This fixes https://github.com/n4r1b/ferrisetw/issues/60

There is no guarantee the wide string pointer is aligned, and thus the vec of u16 values must be reconstructed, there is no way to avoid it. The previous rejection on unaligned pointers led to failing to parse valid values.

Thanks to @vthib for this fix

title: Safer traces, part 2: Trace builder
body:
Fixes #17 
Fixes #45 
Fixes #26 

Sorry, that's a rather large diff, but I did not manage to split it in smaller commits or PR :-/
As stated on the commit message for `Trace now has a Builder`, it's probably easier to read the result of this very commit rather than its changes.

title: Safer traces, part 1: Provider builder
body:
This PR depends on #53 and #55 (as the first few commits are cherry-picked from these branches), that must be merged first.

This introduces a `ProviderBuilder` that must be used to create `Provider`s.
This way:
* setters can be removed from `Provider`, which will ensure it is not modified at runtime (this will help reviewing `unsafe` blocks and resolving #45 )
* the compiler now enforces GUID are set. No need to check it at runtime

title: Fixed error code handling
body: Because some APIs return their error directly without the need to call `GetLastError`

title: Added sample_interval() and max_pmc()
body: Improvements from @DrChat

title: Improved safety
body:
A few tweaks to make ferrisetw slightly less `unsafe`.

Also, we're now using `catch_unwind` to avoid undefined behaviour at a C/Rust boundary

title: Integration tests
body:
This adds integration tests for user trace for kernel trace.

Note that they sometimes crash. This is because of #45 , and this will be fixed in an upcoming MR

title: Added License.md
Fix: re-export types from windows-rs that we expose in our public API
Improved perfs
body:
These changes avoid copying buffers, and avoid calls to TDH in case we're parsing variable-length strings.

Note that I have integration tests that test all these, I'll push them in an upcoming MR (I'm still debugging stuff with them, and they may evolve in the near future)

This closes #25

title: Improved schema locator
body:
* SchemaLocator has interior mutability
This will make it easier to use across various threads

* Simplified SchemaKey
Because windows-rs::core::GUID now implements `Hash`
This probably improves the perfs of ferrisetw a bit

title: [minor] Used a more suited bitflags API
body: `intersects` was working because it compared to a 1-bit value. But what we really want is `contains` here

title: Reviewed parser structs
body:
**This depends on #36, that must be merged first.**

This PR changes the way `Parser`s work and own their data.
* This adds compiler safety guarantees (safe wrappers, alignment of allocated data)
* This improves the API (preferring an `std::iter::Iterator` over a getter with explicit indices, that must be bound-checked)
* This improves performance by:
    * efficiently caching "constant" data (i.e. that does not depend on a given `EVENT_RECORD`), so that it can be reused over various `EVENT_RECORD`s.
    * avoiding cloning some structures
* This adds a "Property not found" error, and fixes #38 (I was too lazy to extract this commit outside of this MR, as it would quickly conflict with other branches)
* This is one step towards a better multi-threading capability of this crate, by removing some `&mut`s and introducing interior mutability

It is probably easier to review this PR commit-by-commit.

Also refs #18 and #25

title: [minor] Added Debug derives
body: That's really a minor change

title: Callbacks now use a reference to an `EVENT_RECORD`
body:
API wise: this now prevents from mutating the given `EVENT_RECORD` (which does not make sense)

Performance-wise: depending on how the compiler optimizes copies of structs that are not mutated, this either does not change much, or save multiple actual copies or `EVENT_RECORD`s, that are quite large objects.
That's a first step towards #25. An upcoming PR will change the `Schema` so that it no longer owns an `EVENT_RECORD`

title: [minor] Shorter unsafe block
body:
That's really a minor change :smile: 
But that makes it easier to review the `unsafe` parts of this crate

title: GitHub actions on doc
body: This will catch errors on the documentation, and make sure upcoming releases will have their doc hosted on `docs.rs`

title: Provider filters
[API] Using a more explicit as_mut_ptr()
body: That's a bit of a nitpick, but that's slightly more idiomatic this way (and we have a slightly better doc + have the compiler enforces that's an `unsafe` function).

title: Fix-up: flipped a condition
body:
Oops, I introduced a bug (flipped condition) in da304e9616a0e581e584d5e6baaed2c4a7cd70dd

That's the fix

title: [API] Better lifetime bound for EventTraceLogfile
body: Removed a comment in favor of a hard compiler check :)

title: Fix: no longer using a pointer to a movable stack item
body:
We're feeding OpenTraceA with an EVENT_TRACE_LOGFILE, which contains (at least) two pointers:
* one to the callback, run on every ETW event This one points to a static location in code
* one to a `PVOID Context` that Windows will give back as argument of the callback This points at `UserTrace.data`, which previously lived on the stack. This means that moving the UserTrace (e.g. by returning it in a function result) would break the pointer. This is fixed by putting UserTrace.data on the heap. It is now the responsability of the ferrisetw developer (and not its user, who was unaware of it) to *not* move it.

This changes the public API, so this means this should be released as a new major number of this crate

Refs #18

title: Using a bitfield for TraceFlags
body:
That's the first change I'd like to integrate into the next major version

Refs #18

title: Doctests
body: Closes #21

title: Added Github Actions
body:
Closes #16 

This is using the basic Rust action automatically suggested by GitHub.
The stock https://github.com/BamPeers/rust-ci-github-actions-workflow you suggested seems to run on Ubuntu. I'm not sure forking and customizing it is worth it.

I think we'll always be able to add clippy, rustfmt, etc. later from this first step

title: Added safe wrappers for ExtendedData
body:
Note that I also have a draft that turns `trace_flags` into a `bitfield` for a clearer API. But that changes the public API, so that would require a major version bump. I'll create an MR later, but I am currently focusing on non-breaking changes :)

(see also #18 for more breaking ideas)

Thanks

title: Fix: flipped condition in Parser::find_property_size
body:
The condition was flipped, compared to krabsetw.
In my case, this sometimes retrieved truncated strings

title: Fix: changed a pointer to a temporary location to a pointer of a (hopefully valid) structure
body: This would really deserve a refactoring, so that the `EventTraceLogfile` at least has a 'lifetime linked to TraceData's. But that would probably mean changing the major version of this crate, so that's left to-do for later :)

title: Minor stuff
body:
Here are definitely minor changes, mainly slight documentation reworks.
I've improved it at a few places to make it more explicit. But I've mostly streamlined it to fit usual Rust-style documentation (e.g. shortened some sentences and removed trivial examples), which is mainly a matter of taste (I can remove these changes if you don't agree with them).

This improved documentation would have helped me (a little) when reading ferrisetw, so I thought I would share it with the others!

I've also ran into some bugs, which I'm fixing and I'll create pull requests for them soon

title: Windows rs upgrade
body:
Hello, thanks for ferrisetw.

I've been experimenting with it for a few days now, and I'd like to extend and improve it (expect other merge requests soon :D ). To start with, I'm upgrading to a newer version of `windows-rs`. (tests are still passing of course. We may want to enable Github Actions on that repo though).

I've split into several commits for better review-ability, but only the last one actually compiles, so you'd probably want to squash them when merging.

title: Fix use-after-free in property_size()
body:
This keeps the name Vec<u16> alive for the call to TdhGetPropertySize,
otherwise it's freed at the end of the statement.

title: Allow cross-compilation with msvc-wine
body: Using the full windows crate as a build-dependencies makes it impossible to cross-compile ferrisetw from linux to windows, as the windows crate tries to link on kernel32.dll and other similar libs that don't exist on linux. By instead only relying on `windows_macros` in the build script, we can avoid this problem.

title: Make KernelProviders proper const, no lazy_static
body: lazy_static makes for some fairly messy documentation as it generates custom types and other noisy content. It's also fairly unnecessary: we can totally build KernelProviders in pure const fn simply by taking the guid directly as argument. Those GUIDS themselves can be built in pure const fn through from_values, at a small ergonomics cost.

title: Fix ‘rip-off’ typo
body:
‘rip off’ is a phrasal verb, ‘rip-off’ is a noun.  Similarly to how
‘set up’ is a phrasal verb and ‘setup’ is sa noun.
